EsminiLib¶

pyesminilib module

pyesminilib.SE_AddObjectSensor(object_id: int, x: float, y: float, z: float, h: float, rangeNear: float, rangeFar: float, fovH: float, maxObj: int) → int¶

Create an ideal object sensor and attach to specified vehicle

Handle to the object to which the sensor should be attached

Position x coordinate of the sensor in vehicle local coordinates

Position y coordinate of the sensor in vehicle local coordinates

Position z coordinate of the sensor in vehicle local coordinates

heading of the sensor in vehicle local coordinates

Horizontal field of view, in degrees

Near value of the sensor depth range

Far value of the sensor depth range

Maximum number of objects theat the sensor can track

Sensor ID (Global index of sensor), -1 if unsucessful

C++: SE_AddObjectSensor(int, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, int) –> int

0 if successful, -1 if not

pyesminilib.SE_Close() → None¶

Stop simulation gracefully. Two purposes: 1. Release memory and 2. Prepare for next simulation, e.g. reset object lists.

C++: SE_Close() –> void

pyesminilib.SE_GetSimTimeStep() → float¶

Get simulation time step in seconds The time step is calculated as difference since last call to same funtion. Clamped to some reasonable values. First call returns smallest delta (typically 1 ms).

C++: SE_GetSimTimeStep() –> float

pyesminilib.SE_GetSimulationTime() → float¶

Get simulation time in seconds

C++: SE_GetSimulationTime() –> float

pyesminilib.SE_Init(oscFilename: str, disable_ctrls: int, use_viewer: int, threads: int, record: int) → int¶

Initialize the scenario engine

Path to the OpenSCEANRIO file

1=Any controller will be disabled 0=Controllers applied according to OSC file

0=no viewer, 1=use viewer

0=single thread, 1=viewer in a separate thread, parallel to scenario engine

Create recording for later playback 0=no recording 1=recording

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_Init(const char *, int, int, int, int) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_InitWithString(oscAsXMLString: str, disable_ctrls: int, use_viewer: int, threads: int, record: int) → int¶

Initialize the scenario engine

OpenSCENARIO XML as string

1=Any controller will be disabled 0=Controllers applied according to OSC file

0=no viewer, 1=use viewer

0=single thread, 1=viewer in a separate thread, parallel to scenario engine

Create recording for later playback 0=no recording 1=recording

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_InitWithString(const char *, int, int, int, int) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_ReportObjectLateralLanePosition(id: int, laneId: int, laneOffset: float) → int¶

Report object lateral position by lane id and lane offset. Useful for an external lateral controller.

Id of the object

Id of the lane

Lateral offset from center of specified lane

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_ReportObjectLateralLanePosition(int, int, float) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_ReportObjectLateralPosition(id: int, t: float) → int¶

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_ReportObjectLateralPosition(int, float) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_ReportObjectPos(id: int, timestamp: float, x: float, y: float, z: float, h: float, p: float, r: float, speed: float) → int¶

Report object position in cartesian coordinates

Id of the object

Timestamp (not really used yet, OK to set 0)

X coordinate

Y coordinate

Z coordinate

Heading / yaw

Pitch

Roll

Speed in forward direction of the enitity

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_ReportObjectPos(int, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_ReportObjectPosXYH(id: int, timestamp: float, x: float, y: float, h: float, speed: float) → int¶

Report object position in limited set of cartesian coordinates x, y and heading, the remaining z, pitch and roll will be aligned to the road surface

Id of the object

Timestamp (not really used yet, OK to set 0)

X coordinate

Y coordinate

Heading / yaw

Speed in forward direction of the enitity

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_ReportObjectPosXYH(int, float, float, float, float, float) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_ReportObjectRoadPos(id: int, timestamp: float, roadId: int, laneId: int, laneOffset: float, s: float, speed: float) → int¶

Report object position in road coordinates

Id of the object

Timestamp (not really used yet, OK to set 0)

Id of the road

Id of the lane

Lateral offset from center of specified lane

Longitudinal distance of the position along the specified road

Speed in forward direction (s axis) of the enitity

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_ReportObjectRoadPos(int, float, int, int, float, float, float) –> int

Id of the object

Speed in forward direction of the enitity

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_ReportObjectSpeed(int, float) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_SetOSITolerances(maxLongitudinalDistance: float, maxLateralDeviation: float) → int¶

Configure tolerances/resolution for OSI road features

Maximum distance between OSI points, even on straight road. Default=50(m)

Control resolution w.r.t. curvature default=0.05(m)

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_SetOSITolerances(double, double) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_SimpleVehicleControlAnalog(handleSimpleVehicle: capsule, dt: float, throttle: float, steering: float) → None¶

Control the speed and steering with floaing values in the range [-1, 1], suitable for driver models. The function also steps the vehicle model, updating its position according to motion state and timestep.

timesStep (s)

Longitudinal control, -1: maximum brake, 0: no acceleration, +1: maximum acceleration

Lateral control, -1: max left, 0: straight, 1: max right

C++: SE_SimpleVehicleControlAnalog(void *, double, double, double) –> void

pyesminilib.SE_SimpleVehicleControlBinary(handleSimpleVehicle: capsule, dt: float, throttle: int, steering: int) → None¶

Control the speed and steering with discreet [-1, 0, 1] values, suitable for keyboard control (e.g. up/none/down). The function also steps the vehicle model, updating its position according to motion state and timestep.

timesStep (s)

Longitudinal control, -1: brake, 0: none, +1: accelerate

Lateral control, -1: left, 0: straight, 1: right

C++: SE_SimpleVehicleControlBinary(void *, double, int, int) –> void

pyesminilib.SE_SimpleVehicleCreate(x: float, y: float, h: float, length: float) → capsule¶

Create an instance of a simplistic vehicle based on a 2D bicycle kincematic model

Initial position X world coordinate

Initial position Y world coordinate

Initial heading

Length of the vehicle

Handle to the created object

C++: SE_SimpleVehicleCreate(float, float, float, float) –> void *

pyesminilib.SE_SimpleVehicleDelete(handleSimpleVehicle: capsule) → None¶

C++: SE_SimpleVehicleDelete(void *) –> void

pyesminilib.SE_Step() → int¶

Step the simulation forward. Time step will be elapsed system (world) time since last step. Useful for interactive/realtime use cases.

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_Step() –> int

pyesminilib.SE_StepDT(dt: float) → int¶

Step the simulation forward with specified timestep

time step in seconds

0 if successful, -1 if not

C++: SE_StepDT(float) –> int

pyesminilib.SE_ViewerShowFeature(featureType: int, enable: bool) → None¶

The SE_GetOSILaneBoundaryIds function the global ids for left, far elft, right and far right lane boundaries

Type of the features, see viewer::NodeMask typedef

Set true to show features, false to hide

C++: SE_ViewerShowFeature(int, bool) –> void
